snippet: Federal and state rulings have cast judges as the most potent critics of the police tactic, raising questions about whether New York City has sidestepped the Constitution.
abstract: Federal and state rulings have cast judges as the most potent critics of the stop-and-frisk tactic used by New York City police, raising questions about whether the city has sidestepped the Constitution; legal experts say the inescapable conclusion is that the city will eventually have to redefine its policy and that the changes will fundamentally alter the way in which police interact with young minority men on the streets.

byline.original: By RUSS BUETTNER and WILLIAM GLABERSON
byline.contributor: Alain Delaquérière and Wendy Ruderman contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Federal and state rulings have cast judges as the most potent critics of the police tactic, raising questions about whether New York City has sidestepped the Constitution.

headline.seo: Stop-and-Frisk May Soon Hit Judicial Roadblocks
headline.main: Courts Putting Stop-and-Frisk Policy on Trial
headline.print_headline: Courts Putting Stop-and-Frisk Policy on Trial
